<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TimedWrite:
```c
int32 OS_TimedWrite(osal_id_t filedes, const void *buffer, size_t nbytes, int32 timeout)
{
    OS_object_token_t token;
    int32             return_code;

    /* Check Parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(buffer);
    OS_CHECK_SIZE(nbytes);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_REFCOUNT, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, filedes, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_GenericWrite_Impl(&token, buffer, nbytes, timeout);
        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
return_code = OS_GenericWrite_Impl(&token, buffer, nbytes, timeout);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The fragment itself does not call any <string.h> functions, so by itself it does not violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (is_rule_violated = false). A specific violation scenario would occur if OS_GenericWrite_Impl uses functions such as memcpy/memmove/strcpy/etc. with the passed buffer and nbytes while there is no contract guaranteeing that the object referenced by buffer is at least nbytes long (or, for string functions, that it is NUL-terminated). For example, if buffer actually points to a smaller object and OS_GenericWrite_Impl does memcpy(dest, buffer, nbytes), this would access beyond the bounds of buffer and violate Rule 21.17.
